componenttext: Can we just get a quick update on Bluestone? And then sort of if you could just elaborate on any contingencies you have put in place, if sort of that production schedule with the producers remains kind of weak?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Jerry.
componenttext: Go ahead, Jerry.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, right now, we're feeling very good about the guidance we issued for the Midstream segment. Production that's flowing is in line with what we had estimated. And actually, we also feel good about the future there. I think the prospect for Southwest
componenttext: I think, right now, we're feeling very good about the guidance we issued for the Midstream segment. Production that's flowing is in line with what we had estimated. And actually, we also feel good about the future there. I think the prospect for Southwestern drilling in that area, as commodity prices continue to strengthen, become more positive as time goes on. So we feel real good about where we are in 2016.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Southwestern was out publicly talking recently and I would say that what we're seeing in our exposure to Southwestern is very consistent with their comments publicly and consistent with the plan that we have out. So when Jerry says we feel good, I think w
componenttext: Southwestern was out publicly talking recently and I would say that what we're seeing in our exposure to Southwestern is very consistent with their comments publicly and consistent with the plan that we have out. So when Jerry says we feel good, I think we've said it's consistent with the expected and is playing out in a way that supports the plan. And then you look down the road, you're beginning to see gas prices for early next year strengthen. I think they were $3-ish when we're talking about them yesterday. And people keep concluding that drilling has pulled back with gas declines at 15% in the United States. And you can only allow 15% decline before -- only allow that for so long before you need to begin to backfill it. And the most obvious places for Southwestern and other people to begin drilling again is in the Northeast Marcellus and in Utica. And the well quality there is still high. So our expectation is when we pushed up gas supplies in the country awfully hard in 2015, people are in a pause, but they're going to -- we're going to need to step back into it. When they do, we expect it to be in the areas we have exposure to.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then can you just maybe elaborate on where you at as far as any potential midstream acquisitions to fill any gaps? Are we still kind of far off?
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then can you just maybe elaborate on where you at as far as any potential midstream acquisitions to fill any gaps? Are we still kind of far off?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're -- we've been in the process of looking at many assets, at least a handful that we're very interested. One of the things that we're finding is that these assets are still trading at premium values. Some recent transactions have illustrated that. We'
componenttext: We're -- we've been in the process of looking at many assets, at least a handful that we're very interested. One of the things that we're finding is that these assets are still trading at premium values. Some recent transactions have illustrated that. We're -- we still have a handful that we're looking at and actively pursuing. I think, in addition to that, we are also looking at greenfield opportunities where we've had most of our success in the last 12 or 14 years in the space. So we've got both in motion to secure incremental growths for this business.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And just last one on your capital outlook. I mean, obviously, you guys have more capital than you can afford and I think historically, sort of the rate impacted the customer's been that ceiling. What -- is there sort of guidance you could pr
componenttext: Okay, got it. And just last one on your capital outlook. I mean, obviously, you guys have more capital than you can afford and I think historically, sort of the rate impacted the customer's been that ceiling. What -- is there sort of guidance you could provide as far as what rate inflation you target when it comes to your spending outlook?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you look at our recent performance, the rates have been negative. So if you go back to 2012 and compare them today, we're down. And even after the current rate case plays out, we'll be flat to down to 2012. So we've been able to work our way through a
componenttext: If you look at our recent performance, the rates have been negative. So if you go back to 2012 and compare them today, we're down. And even after the current rate case plays out, we'll be flat to down to 2012. So we've been able to work our way through a very heavy capital investment period with rates down, and I'm talking about base rates. The future, we've consistently said that we're trying to keep rate increases in the range of inflation, so around 3% as you work your way through one of these intense capital investment cycles. And that's going to require us to both measure the pace of capital investment, but also keep the focus on productivity and continuous improvement that we've had in order to do that. So you know what the blend of capital on O&M is. We got to keep the O&M -- our O&M in recent years, the increase has been 0. And when you can blend the 0 with the increase that come from capital, you can hold it to something reasonable. Now we can't commit the 0 in the future, but we've worked in the past very, very high to keep there, the future. That's unlikely. You can't continue that forever. But we'll work hard on C&I and we will continue to measure the pace of investment. So I think we've said, for example, on our distribution business, there's a lot of demand for investment, but we're going to have to high-grade those projects, do the most important ones and we're really doing that by making customer affordability perspective.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Greg Gordon from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Greg Gordon from Evercore ISI.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think you gave us a good framework for how you're thinking about Power and Industrials in terms of what you have to achieve to hit your guidance. But frankly, I think the stock has underperformed year-to-date, not because people are worried about you
componenttext: So I think you gave us a good framework for how you're thinking about Power and Industrials in terms of what you have to achieve to hit your guidance. But frankly, I think the stock has underperformed year-to-date, not because people are worried about your utilities businesses, but because they're worried about that business and they're worried about the Gas Pipeline and Storage business, and the hurdles to hit the guidance you've laid out. So focusing back on the pipeline business, NEXUS is 2/3 contracted, but these interconnect agreements are pretty substantial. Should we assume that no shorter hauls to those interconnects at a certain percentage of those interconnect commitments could get you well into the range of an acceptable ROE on the pipe? Or do you need to get fully contracted for delivery to gone [ph] at a higher percentage in order to hit your return hurdles or some combination of both?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think both will happen. So I think what interconnect -- these interconnect agreements that we have really provide the pipeline with a lot of diversity on supply opportunities. So our shippers -- long-term shippers on the pipe as well as new shippers
componenttext: So I think both will happen. So I think what interconnect -- these interconnect agreements that we have really provide the pipeline with a lot of diversity on supply opportunities. So our shippers -- long-term shippers on the pipe as well as new shippers that we expect to come on pipe will use these interconnects as ways to deliver to various pipeline -- various markets up and down the pipe, especially in Ohio. And do I expect that those will turn in to real opportunities and real commitments? Absolutely. I think that's a given that, that will happen. I think in terms of more long haul, we are in discussions with several parties to sign up for more long hauls. So I think what you'll see here as the pipeline builds, you'll start to see those interconnects become very active market points for us and provide the, what I would call, lot optionality to future shippers on the pipe. And I think that'll make it a very attractive pipeline that allows us to get more short-haul and long-haul commitments. So I expect both to happen.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, in terms of permitting, we just saw obviously a big negative surprise out of New York last week on a different pipeline project. What are the remaining permits you need beyond just the FERC approval to get this pipe into the ground?
componenttext: Okay, in terms of permitting, we just saw obviously a big negative surprise out of New York last week on a different pipeline project. What are the remaining permits you need beyond just the FERC approval to get this pipe into the ground?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the big one we're waiting for right now is a FERC notice of schedule, which we expect to happen here in the next second quarter. And I think we're in really good shape with that. We're getting very good feedback from the FERC in terms of the quali
componenttext: I think the big one we're waiting for right now is a FERC notice of schedule, which we expect to happen here in the next second quarter. And I think we're in really good shape with that. We're getting very good feedback from the FERC in terms of the quality of our filings. I think a lot of our issues, we're managing quite well, routing issues. We're well underway with our right-of-way acquisition process. And I think, in terms of other permits, there are some large customary permits that come with FERC-regulated pipeline like the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and other various permits, but those are the big ones. I think the FERC order, which we expect by the end of this year and also the other large customary permits, I think they're well -- proceeding very well at this point in time.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then when I look at -- go back and look at your year-end analyst deck, you said your aspiration is to grow operating earnings from $110 million at the midpoint '15 from this segment to $170 million in 2020. If Bluestone were to sort of flat line
componenttext: Okay. And then when I look at -- go back and look at your year-end analyst deck, you said your aspiration is to grow operating earnings from $110 million at the midpoint '15 from this segment to $170 million in 2020. If Bluestone were to sort of flat line from here in terms of its earnings  contribution and you didn't achieve any bolt-on acquisitions, what would that number be?  Would it be significantly lower? Would it be only modestly lower? Because, really, the crux of the issue on people's problem with valuing the stock has concerns over the growth in this business.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I'd say the prospects of Bluestone flatlining are -- I wouldn't frame it that way. We're expanding Bluestone and we're expanding Millennium. And I think the prospects we see are from more of that. So there's -- you were mentioning cancelation of a
componenttext: Yes, so I'd say the prospects of Bluestone flatlining are -- I wouldn't frame it that way. We're expanding Bluestone and we're expanding Millennium. And I think the prospects we see are from more of that. So there's -- you were mentioning cancelation of a pipeline. What we're seeing in the Northeast is a continued pull for gas. They have to have gas for power generation, and the oil to gas conversions continue. So the demand for gas continues to be very, very strong. But there's a real resistance in New York and in other areas of the Northeast to new pipelines. I think that's what that's likely to do. In fact, New York called us out explicitly, is biased towards expansions of existing pipes. So I think the likelihood of some of this resistance you're seeing is that owners of existing positions, including Millennium and Bluestone, will see people coming to them as the most credible and doable pads and expansion pads to market. So I'll just start by saying that I think what we're seeing evolving in the market is a positive for the asset position we have there. Bluestone and Millennium are attached to really good geology and there's resistance in the market to creating new outlets, altogether new outlets, for that geology, which means the existing ones are going to have to expand. And then the long-term growth, NEXUS is an important part of that growth. But when we look out 5 years and ask what is the current dynamic in 2016 really mean for 2020, not much. The gas demand in 2020 is going to be what it's going to be. And power generation conversions are going to be underway. And so the geology is going to have to deliver it, the pipes are going to have to deliver it. Now I think that you could say in the short term "Did production get out in front of itself a bit with a lot of excitement in the market?" The answer to that is obviously yes. So there's an adjustment in the near term and it's changed the path to get to 2020. But the ultimate point that the market needs to achieve in 2020 hasn't changed for either production or delivery through pipes to meet demand. So we really don't see a lot of impact long term, although the path to get there has changed from what it might have been.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Paul Ridzon from KeyBanc.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Paul Ridzon from KeyBanc.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So with Senator Nofs expected to move the bill this week, what could we read into that as far as any progress that may have been made with the schools and with the Chamber of Commerce?
componenttext: So with Senator Nofs expected to move the bill this week, what could we read into that as far as any progress that may have been made with the schools and with the Chamber of Commerce?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Senator Nofs has been in active discussion with the Chamber and I think I will -- I'm not going to put words in the senator's mouth on the coalition that he's put together. I think it'd be better for him to play that up, but he has been in active discu
componenttext: So Senator Nofs has been in active discussion with the Chamber and I think I will -- I'm not going to put words in the senator's mouth on the coalition that he's put together. I think it'd be better for him to play that up, but he has been in active discussion with the Chamber. I think he's also put some provisions in the bill that broadened its interest to his Democratic colleagues. So if you look at the energy efficiency provisions, that's positive in terms of broadening the appeal. He also does have the 30% goal. It's not a mandate, but it's a goal by 2025 for renewables and energy efficiency. That's something the administration has advocated for as have Democrats in the House. So I do think what you see is Senator Nofs listening very, very carefully to whole range of participants, trying to broaden the coalition to a point that he can be successful.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's my understanding that if the bill when we see will have some provision where shoppers who leave actually have the opportunity to come back. How are you thinking about that?
componenttext: It's my understanding that if the bill when we see will have some provision where shoppers who leave actually have the opportunity to come back. How are you thinking about that?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. They -- so they do today and they will in the future. We never thought there would be or should be a prohibition of Retail Open Access, customers coming back. But the -- I think what you'll see when you look at the legislation is that there's a lot
componenttext: Right. They -- so they do today and they will in the future. We never thought there would be or should be a prohibition of Retail Open Access, customers coming back. But the -- I think what you'll see when you look at the legislation is that there's a lot more integrity now in terms of the reliability provisions related to this. So suppliers to the Retail Open Access market need to carry their fair share of local resources -- that needs to be real. And they have ties to real local resources for reliability. Customers who leave the queue, if somebody should come out from under the cap and somebody goes in, will be paying a demand charge. So there's a series of provisions, without me go into all the details, that really do shore up the reliability for that -- the reliability provisions related to that 10% of the market.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Andrew Weisel from Macquarie Capital.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Andrew Weisel from Macquarie Capital.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question, first on the distribution reliability. You're showing the $6.5 billion 10-year plan here. You've previously talked about potentially the next will be over $10 billion even. Remind us, is that -- the potential to add some of the extra stuff
componenttext: Quick question, first on the distribution reliability. You're showing the $6.5 billion 10-year plan here. You've previously talked about potentially the next will be over $10 billion even. Remind us, is that -- the potential to add some of the extra stuff there, does that depend on your ability to cut costs or the state environment -- state energy law? Or what might be some of the swinging factors of getting that into the plan and when might those decisions be made?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think what we've said on that one is that there's a lot of demand in our distribution system. It's an aging infrastructure system. As we evaluate the need, a need currently outstrips what we think customer affordability will enable. So in order for u
componenttext: So I think what we've said on that one is that there's a lot of demand in our distribution system. It's an aging infrastructure system. As we evaluate the need, a need currently outstrips what we think customer affordability will enable. So in order for us to do more of that, to kind of work our way into that backlog, it would depend on us finding productivity opportunities or if there were things, for example, that evolved on the generation side that were -- required less capital, we could conceivably push some of this needed investment in. But we are kind of calibrating how much of that we do based upon affordability because we've consistently said that companies that don't pay careful attention to that when they're going through a big investment cycle end up losing. You just need to go through these cycles in a way where your customers feel their affordability is workable. So that's really what determines how much of the $10.5 billion we would spend versus the $6.5 billion. And you're right, if we can find either capital offsets or productivity offsets. Those are the things that will enable us to do more of that needed investment.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Next question is related to Millennium in New York. Someone already made reference to the different pipeline basically getting shut down because of it -- because of regulators not supporting pipeline expansion there. Do you see any risk to th
componenttext: Okay, great. Next question is related to Millennium in New York. Someone already made reference to the different pipeline basically getting shut down because of it -- because of regulators not supporting pipeline expansion there. Do you see any risk to the plans for Millennium specifically?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, our answer is that with our pipeline investments that we've been able to secure through the FERC as well as what New York regulators, for example, we've been able to secure an expansion of Bluestone most recently through the New York regulators, and
componenttext: Well, our answer is that with our pipeline investments that we've been able to secure through the FERC as well as what New York regulators, for example, we've been able to secure an expansion of Bluestone most recently through the New York regulators, and that's actually a pipeline regulated by New York in New York. And then secondly, we secured the last 2 compressor expansions for Millennium through FERC as well as working with New York regulators. So I think what we're -- as Gerry described earlier, I think the regulators are pointing towards existing assets as ways to expand into a growing market. So as you know, we've got a Millennium Pipeline expansion where we've made a FERC refiling, and that's going well. We are in active conversations with regulators in Albany on that expansion and we feel that those conversations are going well. So we -- at this point, we feel pretty confident that we'll secure our expansion approvals for Millennium.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Bluestone runs both in Pennsylvania and New York, so you need approvals out of both states. But our recent expansion of Bluestone, our conversations were very productive. And as Jerry mentioned, same is true for Millennium. So our experience has been t
componenttext: So Bluestone runs both in Pennsylvania and New York, so you need approvals out of both states. But our recent expansion of Bluestone, our conversations were very productive. And as Jerry mentioned, same is true for Millennium. So our experience has been that when you're -- when the need is clear and you're dealing with an existing asset with, I guess, you'd say more modest implications, you can have a productive conversation and work your way through it. And that's what our last 2 rounds of discussion in Albany have produced.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very good. Last question, you added a comment there about continuing to evaluate current year equity needs. You previously talked about targeting $100 million of equity in 2016. Which direction are you thinking? Are you trying to find ways to maybe reduce
componenttext: Very good. Last question, you added a comment there about continuing to evaluate current year equity needs. You previously talked about targeting $100 million of equity in 2016. Which direction are you thinking? Are you trying to find ways to maybe reduce that number? Or is that more an implication that if you were to make an acquisition, for example, in the midstream business, that maybe you would issue some equity?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We always go into the year, we have a big focus on cash in the company. And so we did indicate that over the 3-year period, it's $200 million to $300 million and that we potentially can do up to $100 million this year, so we're assessing that. Our goal wo
componenttext: We always go into the year, we have a big focus on cash in the company. And so we did indicate that over the 3-year period, it's $200 million to $300 million and that we potentially can do up to $100 million this year, so we're assessing that. Our goal would be, if we can, to make that 0. It's hard really to say that. We're going to have to see how the year plays out and the cash flow the company plays that out. I'd still say that $200 million to $300 million over the 3-year period is still a good number. And we're assessing how much do we actually need to do to get $200 million to $300 million this year.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So could it be more timing?
componenttext: So could it be more timing?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I think, what Peter's indicating is that I think our Q says up to $100 million, which implies that the bias would be down given everything we know. But your comment was also right. If we found a great opportunity for investment that we thought cr
componenttext: Well, as I think, what Peter's indicating is that I think our Q says up to $100 million, which implies that the bias would be down given everything we know. But your comment was also right. If we found a great opportunity for investment that we thought create a lot of value, that could be the thing that pushes you up through the high end of equity. So those are really the 2 balances. As Peter said, we were always working cash and cash flow, and we're off to a good start. So our hope would be to be playing out in the up 2 zone, not the at a 100. And the one potential offset is if we found a great investment.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And will the equity need to have an impact on the dividend decision, which you typically announce in June and have a relatively low payout ratio?
componenttext: And will the equity need to have an impact on the dividend decision, which you typically announce in June and have a relatively low payout ratio?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We typically will grow the dividend in line with the earnings versus the amount of -- so the amount of equity we're issuing is not going to have an impact on our dividend decision.
componenttext: No. We typically will grow the dividend in line with the earnings versus the amount of -- so the amount of equity we're issuing is not going to have an impact on our dividend decision.

componenttext: Well, I will just wrap up by, again, thanking everybody for joining the call this morning. Look forward to talking to you soon.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to today's DTE Energy Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded.At this time, I would like to hand the conference over to Barb Tuckfield. Please go ahead.
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to today's DTE Energy Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded.
At this time, I would like to hand the conference over to Barb Tuckfield. Please go ahead.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steffi, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the Safe Harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes referen
componenttext:
Thank you, Steffi, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the Safe Harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes references to operating earnings, which is a non-GAAP financial measure. Please refer to the reconciliation of GAAP net income to operating earnings provided in the appendix of today's presentation.
With us this morning are Gerry Anderson, our Chairman and CEO; Jerry Norcia, our President and CEO; and Peter Oleksiak, our Senior Vice President and CFO. We also have members of the management team with us to call on during the Q&A session.
And now I'll turn it over to Gerry to start this morning's call

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Barb, and good morning, everybody. Thanks very much for joining us. I'm going to start with an overview of our results in the second quarter as well as some key developments of the company over the past quarter. And then I'm going to turn
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Barb, and good morning, everybody. Thanks very much for joining us. I'm going to start with an overview of our results in the second quarter as well as some key developments of the company over the past quarter. And then I'm going to turn things over to Peter for a financial update, then we'll wrap up and take some Q&A.
So moving on to Slide 5. We continue to make good progress on a number of fronts of this year. So with a successful first stamp of year under our belts, I feel really good about our year-to-date financial results. And based upon those strong results, we're increasing our operating earnings, we'll talk about a bit more about that in a minute. We also recently increased our dividend for the seventh consecutive year, which continues to be over 100-year history of issuing dividends at the company.
Rachel Eubanks [ph] was appointed by Governor Snyder to serve the remainder of John [indiscernible] 6-year term that expires about a year now -- a year from now, July 2, 2017. Her experience is in the area of finance, so it includes project finance, municipal bond refinancings, credit enhanced financing, variables and transactions and so forth. She also, over her career, has provided investment banking support on financial advisory and investment engagements for state government, government authorities, municipalities and nonprofit organizations. So as we look forward in Michigan to a really heavy period of investment and our infrastructure, I think that her understanding of finance will be a good complement to the skills of the current commissioners, we certainly will have somebody there who understands cash flows, balance sheet issues and so forth at the company that goes through a heavy investment period.
Thanks to the hard work of our employees. For the third consecutive year, DTE was ranked second and the Midwest by J.D. Power in overall electric residential customer satisfaction, that's in the large utility category. And this was our sixth consecutive year of being in the top quartile of that survey. We also achieved our best safety record in the company's history in the first 6 months, and that was by a wide margin, which I'm particularly proud of, I think it says something about where our employees heads are. And if we can keep this performance, we may just be the safest company in the industry this year. And earlier this year, we won our fourth consecutive Gallup place award, and our results placed us in the top 12% of the companies worldwide in terms of employee engagement.
On the NEXUS front, that pipeline continues to progress. The project reached another important regulatory milestone, which sets us up nicely. We can meet our [indiscernible] late next year, so I'll talk a bit more about NEXUS and those developments in a few minutes.
Now I'll move on to Slide 6, and give you some color on our second quarter financial results. So in the second quarter, we build upon what were really positive first quarter results. We delivered second quarter earnings per share of $0.98, which we're actually great about. As you know, we came into this year expecting warm weather. We planned for it and that play through in our first quarter results. And we, based in the first and second quarters, come out of the first half of the year, very well-positioned and we now have the potential to reinvest some of the weather-related favorability that may occur in the third quarter. We're seeing a hot July and there's a warm August projected as well. So given the strong results for the first half of year, we're increasing the midpoint of our guidance by $0.12, from $4.93 to $5.05. And given that, we now have a solid path to achieving our 10th consecutive year of meeting or beating our earnings targets.
We've also been growing our dividend, along with earnings, and we just recently increased the dividend by $0.16 a share and our balance sheet continue to be in great shape. So bottom line, I feel really good about our finance position as we head into the second half of 2016.
So moving on to Slide 7 for a little more color on earnings and dividends. We talked for years to investors about delivering 5% to 6% annual earnings per share growth and appearing that with healthy dividend growth. Now on the right-hand side of the slide in ovals, you can see that our actual earnings per share growth over the past 5 years or so, has been 6.5%. So really 1% above that 5% to 6%. And we have grown our dividends at 5% to 6% rate.
I also mentioned a minute ago that we're increasing guidance from a midpoint of 4 93 to 5 0 5.  Fundamentally, this is driven by a strong performance in our electric business and in our Gas Storage and Pipelines business as well as very solid first half in our Energy Trading operations. As I stated the minute ago and keeping with the commitment to growing dividends with earnings, we increased our dividend per share from $2.92 to $3.08, which was a 5.5% increase.
Now I'll move on to Slide 8 now and discuss the significant development related to our powerplant fleet that occurred in the second quarter. So in June, we announced closure plans for 8 coal-fired generating units. And this is announcement, combined with our decision to cease operation in 3 coal-fired plants, which happened in April, means that we will replace 11 aging coal-fired generation units at 3 sites, totaling 2.5 gigawatts on or before 2023. Much of this coal-based slow generation will be a replaced with natural gas generation, but we also intend to continue to invest in wind and solar to ensure we keep the mix in our portfolio that we want. This portion of what is a longer-term transition plan for our fleet will require about $3 billion investment.
By 2030, we'd expect to retire an additional gigawatt of coal-fired generation, which would bring total retirements to 3.5 gigawatts. And in doing that, our reliance on coal would decline by about 60%, and we'd expect to roughly double our current 10% renewable capacity and to use more gas fire generation in a base load role.
Obviously, emissions through 2030 will be down fundamentally as well. So CO2, we project, would be down about 40% versus 2005 levels and our conventional emissions would be down sharply as well.
Moving on to Slide 9. NEXUS continues to move forward and make good progress. So NEXUS received its schedule on May 17th of this year. The project also recently received a favorable draft environmental impact report or EIS, from the [indiscernible] . We expect the final EIS by the end of November and that would allow for a certificate of construction by the end of February of 2017, which would set us up nicely for the November and service date next year. We are progressing on a right-of-way acquisition and detailed engineering plans and we continue to work constructively with Ferc and other regulatory agencies.
In addition, in June, we received a letter of support for the NEXUS projects from the Michigan Agency for Energy, so the Michigan Agency fior Energy takes the lead on energy policy for the administration. We also received a letter support from the Michigan Economic Development Corporation, which is the state's primary economic development agency. In addition, a recent Michigan Public service commission staff brief our electric power cover a case, that's our fuel plus case, stated I quote, "staff believes that DTE Electric NEXUS Pipeline project is reasonable as proposed in DTE Electric's application, it's testimony and this exhibits in this case." So we are gratified to have staff weigh in and say, "I think this project would benefit customers and benefit the state." In addition, we had letters of support offered by both Senator Knobs and Representative Nesbit, they are the chairs in House energy committee so there's a lot of support in the state of Michigan for this pipeline moving forward.
So that we really believe in the fundamentals of this pipe, it serves arguably the best dry gas production geology and country. I can ask that geology directly to growing markets in Michigan and Ontario, and [indiscernible] pipeline connects into Chicago and Wisconsin as well. The pipe also connects directly to the largest collection of market area storage in the country in Michigan and in the Western Ontario. The pipe has 3 strong utility sponsors, and up to 1.75 BCF of signed interconnect agreements in Northern Ohio and the pipe remains on schedule even as many other by pipes serving the Utica region struggle with delays. And given this, we can do to think that NEXUS is going to be a valuable addition to our guest or pipeline portfolio.
And with that, I'm going to turn things over to Peter Oleksiak to cover our financial results in more detail. So Peter, over to you

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gerry. Good morning to everyone. I'd like to start with Slide 11. Gerry mentioned DTE's operating earnings for the second quarter were $0.98 per share. And for reference, reported earnings were $0.84 per share. For a detailed breakdown EPS by segm
componenttext:
Thanks, Gerry. Good morning to everyone. I'd like to start with Slide 11. Gerry mentioned DTE's operating earnings for the second quarter were $0.98 per share. And for reference, reported earnings were $0.84 per share. For a detailed breakdown EPS by segment including a record solution to GAAP reported earnings, please refer to slide 24 and the appendix.
Slide 11 shows our quarter-over-quarter operating earnings by segment. Starting at the top of with the 2 utilities. We experienced usually -- unusual weather this quarter, which gave a boost to both utilities. Now April was colder than normal while May and June were warmer than normal. [indiscernible] unusual weather in the quarter create a both heating and cooling load causing earnings to both utilities to be up quarter-over-quarter.
DTE Electric's earnings were $135 million for the second quarter this year compared to $111 million last year. I'm studying the weather in last year's rate case DTE Electric's earnings were lower due to the absence of a revenue decoupling mechanism amortization in 2016. You may recall, this revenue decoupling amortization was part of our strategy that extended the timeframe in between rate cases by 4 years. We've increased guidance in both segments given the warm weather through June. And for the breakdown DTE Electric's quarter-over-quarter results can be found on Slide 19.
For DTE Gas earnings for the second quarter were up $13 million compared to a loss of $7 million last year. The [indiscernible] was due to cooler weather and April of this year, increased revenue related to our infrastructure replacement program and planned initiatives in response of the warm weather we experienced in the first quarter.
As we discussed in our first quarter call, we went into the year anticipating warmer-than-normal weather for the winter and we planned for it. With this advanced planning, we were able to stay on track to meet guidance.
Moving down the page, Gas Storage and Pipelines earnings were $35 million for the quarter. Earnings for the quarter were up $10 million over last year due to higher pipeline and gathering earnings from production that came online in the second half of 2015. We continue to see strength in the segment even in current conditions. We've adjusted the midpoint of guidance upwards with segments, which I'll discuss in a minute.
Moving further down the slide, earnings for our Power and Industrial Projects were $17 million for the quarter, down $1 million from the second quarter last year. This decrease is primarily driven by lower earnings in the fuel sector, offset by variable volumes from additional projects that came online in the fourth quarter of last year.
Earnings for cover and other were negative $23 million for the second quarter of this year, $10 million favorable over last year due to the timing off axis.
So earnings were $177 million for a gross segment for the second quarter or $0.98 per share compared to $134 million or $0.75 per share last year.
To round out our operating earnings, we indlude the results of our Energy Trading business. At Energy Trading, the accounting earnings were 0, down $3 million from the second quarter last year, driven by lower realized power performance. Trading's economic contribution for the second quarter of 2016 was $12 million. Trading is having another stong economic year, actually $30 million year-to-date, economic contributions. A portion of the year-to-date economic performance would flow to the total year operating income results. I will talk more in a minute on the new guidance for our trading segment. By [ph] 22, the appendix campaign's our standard Energy Trading reconciliation, shown on both on economic and accounting performance.
Let me now turn to Slide 12 in the EPS guidance for the year. [indiscernible] as been mentioned at the start of the call based in our financial results in the first half of the year, we are increasing our midpoint of the 2016 EPS cents [ph] by $0.12 from $4.93 to $5.05 for DTE Energy. Our EPS guidance range for DTE Energy is now $4.91 to $5.19. And $4.85 to $5.08 for our growth segments. Our guidance increase for our gross segments is driven by strong start to the year at our DTE Electric and Gas, Storage and Pipeline segments. The warmer-than-normal continues with be the remainder of the summer. We will initiate and invest plan at our DTE Electric to put the incremental revenue in cash back in the customer-centric assets and activities.
For our GSP segment, the new drilling plans to Southwestern announced last week in the Blue storm region may provide outside to 2016 and set us up nicely for 2017. Operating earnings guidance for these segments increased from a midpoint of 5 92 to 5 97 at DTE Electric and $110 million to $113 million at our Gas, Storage and Pipeline segment.
As I just mentioned on our prior page, our DTE Energy business is off to a strong economic start. We have raised our earnings guidance from 0 to a range of $10 million to $20 million up for this year. Energy Trading is not part of our growth segment and we let the business be opportunistic versus setting the sign of operating earnings targets. So we conservatively set the original guidance at 0 then typically update earnings guidance as we said to result for the first 2 quarters and to recover our operating cost. Given the strong results in the first half of this year, we are increasing the guidance for Energy Trading, we'll give another balance of that in the third quarter based on economic results for the first 3 quarters.
Moving on to Slide 13. In addition, [indiscernible] earnings results for the year, our balance sheet remains strong and we'll continue to provide the foundation for our long term growth plans. This slide lays out a cash flow and CapEx to the first half of the year. Cash from operations was $1.3 billion. I saw a strong performance across several business units, which is driving the increase over the same period last year and puts us a little ahead of our plan this year. We invested $1 billion of CapEx to the second quarter. And on the right side of the page, you can see the breakout by business units.
DTE Electric's CapEx decreased was due to the timing of operational investment and lower new generation of spend with the acquisition of large gas back in the first quarter of 2015. The 9 [ph] utilities are higher than last year, driven by the timing of projects but particularly, our Gas, Storage and pipeline segment.
The fund is CapEx program and refinanced the [indiscernible] debt we have issued, $600 million of long-term debt financing this year. They've been consistent in our messaging that maintaining a strong balance sheet is the priority.
Slide 14 provides the key balance sheet metrics we target and monitor, which is FFO to debt and leverage. This slide shows the projected level for each metric.
Our 2016 financing plan is on track and we plan to issue up to $100 million of equity this year. However, given the strength of the cash flows we've experienced to date, we are looking at the possibility of differing equity issuance in the next 2 years. A 3-year projected equity needs remain at the $200 million to $300 million, which is just a small fraction of the total capital spend at the [indiscernible] timeframe.
Our disciplined approach to maintaining a strong balance sheet across the years has proven to be valuable. It sets up nicely as we enter a period of incremental infrastructure improvements and investment set of utilities and funding the growth plans that are non-utility businesses.
Let me wrap up on Slide 16 and then again move to questions and answers. We've had a very good quarter as well as the first half of the year. We were able to raise our EPS guidance, setting up nicely to send our streak to 10 consecutive years of meeting or exceeding our initial EPS guidance. This will be the seventh consecutive year that we've increased our dividends. This quarter, we announced [indiscernible] and retirements that will bring cleaner energy to our customers and considerable investments to our electric utility, maintaining a strong balance sheet will allow us to invest in the utilities and pursue growth opportunities at our non-utility businesses.
Before I open up the Q&A, our call will not be complete without a quick update on my hometown Detroit Tigers. Now this -- the good news is that we won 50 games so far this year. The bad news is that we bought about as many games as well. Justing [indiscernible] looking better recently as she won last night in Boston [indiscernible] need to heat up, of course, they have a chance. A lot of seasons left on remaining optimistic.
With that, I like to thank everyone for joining us this morning. Also Steffie, you can open lines up for questions

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we continue to work this summer with some of the principles. I think what's likely come fall is that there will be activity again in the Senate. We kind of ran out of time there with all the dynamics in the legislators between plants, roads, Detroit sc
componenttext: So we continue to work this summer with some of the principles. I think what's likely come fall is that there will be activity again in the Senate. We kind of ran out of time there with all the dynamics in the legislators between plants, roads, Detroit schools and states. Sick activity in the Senate and something to get passed in the Senate in the session in September, but we'll see. And then I think everybody will last the election and see what the election dynamics mean for the Michigan legislator with the possibility that we would pick back up and pass legislation in the lane session at the end of the year. So legislation is going the pass this year would be in the line deck. Well, I guess, I'll keep in mind an approach that this is not so much a financial discussion. In fact, it's not a financial discussion, it really doesn't affect our 5-year plan, but it is an energy reliability discussion. And at some point or another, we need to get -- we need to be clear on who's building powerplants for 10% of the market. And right now, the answer is nobody. And until we get policy in place that ensures that somebody does it, there's risk reliability issues with state. So if it doesn't happen this year, it will happen at some point when it becomes clear that we need to take care of that.

Good day, and welcome to today's DTE Energy Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded.
At this time, I would like to hand the conference over to Barb Tuckfield. Please go ahead.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Steffi, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the safe harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes referen
componenttext:
Thank you, Steffi, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the safe harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes references to operating earnings, which is a non-GAAP financial measure. Please refer to the reconciliation of GAAP net income to operating earnings provided in the appendix of today's presentation.
With us this morning are Gerry Anderson, our Chairman and CEO; Jerry Norcia, our President and COO; and Peter Oleksiak, our Senior Vice President and CFO. We also have members of the management team with us to call on during the Q&A session.
And now I'll turn it over to Gerry to start this morning's call

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Barb, and good morning, everybody. Thanks very much for joining us. I am going to start with an overview of our results in the second quarter as well as some key developments at the company over the past quarter. And then I'm going to tur
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Barb, and good morning, everybody. Thanks very much for joining us. I am going to start with an overview of our results in the second quarter as well as some key developments at the company over the past quarter. And then I'm going to turn things over to Peter for a financial update. Then we'll wrap up and take some Q&A.
So moving on to Slide 5. We continue to make good progress on a number of fronts this year. So with a successful first half of the year under our belts, I feel really good about our year-to-date financial results. And based upon those strong results, we're increasing our operating earnings per share guidance. We'll talk a bit about more of that -- more about that in a minute. We also recently increased our dividend for the seventh consecutive year, which continues the over 100-year history of issuing dividends at the company.
Rachael Eubanks was appointed by Governor Snyder to serve the remainder of John Quackenbush's 6-year term that expires about a year now -- a year from now, July 2, 2017. Her experience is in the area of finance, so it includes project finance, municipal bond refinancings, credit enhanced financing, variable and auction-rate transactions and so forth. She also, over her career, has provided investment banking support on financial advisory and investment engagements for state government, government authorities, municipalities and nonprofit organizations. So as we look forward in Michigan to a really heavy period of investment in our infrastructure, I think that her understanding of finance will be a good complement to the skills of the current commissioners. We certainly will have somebody there who understands cash flows, balance sheet issues and so forth as the company goes through a heavy investment period.
Thanks to the hard work of our employees, for the third consecutive year, DTE was ranked second in the Midwest by J.D. Power in overall electric residential customer satisfaction. That's in the large utility category. And this was our sixth consecutive year of being in the top quartile of that survey. We also achieved our best safety record in the company's history in the first 6 months, and that was by a wide margin, which I'm particularly proud of. I think it says something about where our employees' heads are. And if we can keep this performance, we may just be the safest company in the industry this year. And earlier this year, we won our fourth consecutive Gallup Great Workplace Award, and our results placed us in the top 12% of companies worldwide in terms of employee engagement.
On the NEXUS front, that pipeline continues to progress. The project reached another important regulatory milestone, which sets us up nicely to meet our in-service date late next year. So I'll talk a bit more about NEXUS and those developments in a few minutes.
Now I'll move on to Slide 6 and give you some color on our second quarter financial results. So in the second quarter, we build upon what were really positive first quarter results. We delivered second quarter earnings per share of $0.98, which I feel great about. As you know, we came into this year expecting warm weather. We planned for it, and that played through in our first quarter results. And we, based on the first and second quarters, come out of the first half of the year very well positioned, and we now have the potential to reinvest some of the weather-related favorability that may occur in the third quarter. We're seeing a hot July, and there's a warm August projected as well. So given the strong results of the first half of the year, we're increasing the midpoint of our guidance by $0.12, from $4.93 to $5.05. And given that, we now have a solid path to achieving our 10th consecutive year of meeting or beating our earnings targets.
We've also been growing our dividend, along with earnings, and we just recently increased the dividend by $0.16 a share, and our balance sheet continues to be in great shape. So bottom line, I feel really good about our finance position as we head into the second half of 2016.
So moving on to Slide 7 for a little more color on earnings and dividend. We've talked for years to investors about delivering 5% to 6% annual earnings per share growth and then pairing that with healthy dividend growth. And on the right-hand side of the slide in the ovals, you can see that our actual earnings per share growth over the past 5 years or so has been 6.5%. So really 1% above that 5% to 6%. And we have grown our dividends at 5% to 6% rate.
I also mentioned a minute ago that we're increasing guidance from a midpoint of $4.93 to $5.05.  Fundamentally, this is driven by a strong performance in our electric business and in our Gas Storage and Pipelines business as well as a very solid first half in our Energy Trading operations. As I stated a minute ago and keeping with the commitment to grow dividends with earnings, we increased our dividend per share from $2.92 to $3.08, which was a 5.5% increase.
So I'm going to move on to Slide 8 now and discuss a significant development related to our powerplant fleet that occurred in the second quarter. So in June, we announced closure plans for 8 coal-fired generating units. And this announcement, combined with our decision to cease operation at 3 coal-fired plants, which happened in April, means that we will replace 11 aging coal-fired generation units at 3 sites, totaling 2.5 gigawatts on or before 2023. Much of this coal-based slow generation will be replaced with natural gas generation, but we also intend to continue to invest in wind and solar to ensure that we keep the mix in our portfolio that we want. This portion of what is a longer-term transition plan for our fleet will require about $3 billion of investment.
By 2030, we'd expect to retire an additional gigawatt of coal-fired generation, which would bring total retirements to 3.5 gigawatts. And in doing that, our reliance on coal would decline by about 60%, and we'd expect to roughly double our current 10% renewable capacity and to use more gas-fired generation in a base load role [ph].
Obviously, emissions through 2030 will be down fundamentally as well. So CO2, we project, would be down about 40% versus 2005 levels, and our conventional emissions would be down sharply as well.
Moving on to Slide 9. NEXUS continues to move forward and make good progress. So NEXUS received its FERC Notice of Schedule on May 17 of this year. The project also recently received a favorable draft environmental impact report, or EIS, from the FERC. We expect the final EIS by the end of November, and that would allow for a certificate of construction by the end of February of 2017, which would set us up nicely for the November in-service date next year. We're progressing on right-of-way acquisitions and detailed engineering plans, and we continue to work constructively with FERC and other regulatory agencies.
In addition, in June, we received a letter of support for the NEXUS project from the Michigan Agency for Energy, so the Michigan Agency for Energy takes the lead on energy policy for the administration. We also received a letter support from the Michigan Economic Development Corporation, which is the state's primary economic development agency. In addition, a recent Michigan Public Service Commission staff brief on our electric power cost recovery case, that's our fuel clause case, stated, and I quote, "staff believes that DTE Electric's participation in the NEXUS Pipeline project is reasonable as proposed in DTE Electric's application, its testimony and its exhibits in this case." So we were gratified to have staff weigh in saying they think this project would benefit customers and benefit the state. In addition, we had letters of support offered by both Senator Nofs and Representative Nesbitt. They are the chairs of the Senate and House energy committees. So there's a lot of support in the state of Michigan for this pipeline moving forward.
So look, we really believe in the fundamentals of this pipe. It serves arguably the best dry gas production geology in the country. It connects that geology directly to growing markets in Michigan and Ontario. And then via our Vector Pipeline, it connects into Chicago and Wisconsin as well. The pipe also connects directly to the largest collection of market area storage in the country in Michigan and in Western Ontario. The pipe has 3 strong utility sponsors and up to 1.75 BCF of signed interconnect agreements in Northern Ohio and the pipe remains on schedule even as many other by pipes serving the Utica region struggle with delays. And given this, we continue to think that NEXUS is going to be a valuable addition to our Gas Storage and Pipelines portfolio.
And with that, I am going to turn things over to Peter Oleksiak to cover our financial results in more details. Peter, over to you

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gerry, and good morning to everyone. I'd like to start with Slide 11. Gerry mentioned DTE's operating earnings for the second quarter were $0.98 per share. And for reference, reported earnings were $0.84 per share. For a detailed breakdown of EPS
componenttext:
Thanks, Gerry, and good morning to everyone. I'd like to start with Slide 11. Gerry mentioned DTE's operating earnings for the second quarter were $0.98 per share. And for reference, reported earnings were $0.84 per share. For a detailed breakdown of EPS by segment, including a reconciliation to GAAP reported earnings, please refer to Slide 24 in the appendix.
Slide 11 shows our quarter-over-quarter operating earnings by segment. Starting at the top of the page with the 2 utilities, we experienced unusually -- unusual weather this quarter, which gave a boost to both utilities. April was colder than normal, while May and June were warmer than normal. And this unusual weather in the quarter created both heating and cooling load, causing earnings at both utilities to be up quarter-over-quarter.
DTE Electric's earnings were $135 million for the second quarter this year compared to $111 million last year. Studying the weather in last year's rate case, DTE Electric's earnings were lower due to the absence of the revenue decoupling mechanism amortization in 2016. As you may recall, this revenue decoupling amortization was part of our strategy that extended the time frame in between rate cases by 4 years. We have increased guidance for this segment given the warm weather through June. A further breakdown of DTE Electric's quarter-over-quarter results can be found on Slide 19.
For DTE Gas, earnings for the second quarter were $13 million compared to a loss of $7 million last year. The variance was due to cooler weather in April of this year, increased revenue related to our infrastructure replacement program and planned initiatives in response of the warm weather we experienced in the first quarter.
As we discussed in our first quarter call, we went into the year anticipating warmer-than-normal weather for the winter, and we planned for it. With this advanced planning, we were able to stay on track to meet guidance.
Moving down the page, Gas Storage and Pipelines earnings were $35 million for the quarter. Earnings for the quarter were up $10 million over last year due to higher pipeline and gathering earnings from production that came online in the second half of 2015. We continue to see strength in this segment, even in current conditions. We have adjusted the midpoint of guidance upwards for this segment, which I will discuss in a minute.
Moving further down the slide, earnings for our Power and Industrial Projects were $17 million for the quarter, down $1 million from the second quarter last year. This decrease is primarily driven by lower earnings in the steel sector, offset by favorable REF volumes from additional projects that came online in the fourth quarter of last year.
Earnings for Corporate and Other were negative $23 million for the second quarter this year, $10 million favorable over last year due to the timing of taxes.
So earnings were $177 million for our growth segments for the second quarter or $0.98 per share compared to the $134 million or $0.75 per share last year.
To round out our operating earnings, we include the results of our Energy Trading business. At Energy Trading, the accounting earnings were 0, down $3 million from the second quarter last year, driven by lower realized power performance. Trading's economic contribution for the second quarter of 2016 was $12 million. Trading is having another strong economic year, actually [ph] $30 million year-to-date economic contribution. A portion of the year-to-date economic performance will flow through the total year operating income results. I will talk more in a minute on the new guidance for our Trading segment. Slide 22 of the appendix contains our standard Energy Trading reconciliation, showing both economic and accounting performance.
Let me now turn to Slide 12 and the EPS guidance for the year. As Gerry Anderson mentioned at the start of the call, based on our financial results in the first half of the year, we are increasing our midpoint of the 2016 EPS guidance by $0.12 from $4.93 to $5.05 for DTE Energy. Our EPS guidance range for DTE Energy is now $4.91 to $5.19 and $4.85 to $5.08 for our growth segments. Our guidance increase for our growth segments is driven by a strong start to the year at our DTE Electric and Gas Storage and Pipeline segments. If the warmer-than-normal weather continues through the remainder of the summer, we will initiate an invest plan at our DTE Electric to put the incremental revenue and cash back into customer-centric assets and activities.
For our GSP segment, the new drilling plans to Southwestern announced last week in the Bluestone region may provide upside to 2016 and sets us up nicely for 2017. Operating earnings guidance for these segments increased from a midpoint of $5.92 to $5.97 at DTE Electric and $110 million to $113 million at our Gas Storage and Pipeline segment.
As I just mentioned on the prior page, our DTE Energy business is off to a strong economic start. We have raised our earnings guidance from 0 to a range of $10 million to $20 million for this year. Energy Trading is not part of our growth segment, and we let the business be opportunistic versus setting a defined operating earnings targets. So we conservatively set the original guidance at 0, then typically update earnings guidance as we [indiscernible] the results for the first 2 quarters after we cover operating costs. Given the strong results in the first half this year, we are increasing the guidance for Energy Trading. We'll give another guidance update in the third quarter based on economic results for the first 3 quarters.
Moving on to Slide 13. In addition to solid earnings results for the year, our cash flow and balance sheet remains strong and will continue to provide the foundation for our long-term growth plans. This slide lays out our cash flow and CapEx through the first half of the year. Cash from operations was $1.3 billion. We saw strong performance across several business units, which is driving the increase over the same period last year and puts us a little ahead of our plan this year. We invested $1 billion of CapEx through the second quarter. And on the right side of the page, you can see the breakout by business unit.
DTE Electric's CapEx decrease was due to the timing of operational investment and lower new generation of spend with the acquisition of a large gas peaker back in the first quarter of 2015. The 9 [ph] utilities are higher than last year, driven by the timing of projects, particularly in our Gas Storage and Pipeline segment.
To fund this CapEx program and refinance maturing debt, we have issued $600 million in long-term debt financing this year. We've been consistent in our messaging over the years that maintaining a strong balance sheet is a priority.
Slide 14 provides the key balance sheet metrics we target and monitor, which is FFO to debt and leverage. This slide shows the projected level for each metric.
Our 2016 financing plan is on track. We plan to issue up to $100 million of equity this year. However, given the strong strength of the cash flows we have experienced to date, we are looking at the possibility of deferring equity issuance into the next 2 years. 3-year projected equity needs remain at the $200 million to $300 million, which is just a small fraction of the total capital spend over that time frame.
Our disciplined approach to maintaining a strong balance sheet across the years has proven to be valuable and sets us up nicely as we enter a period of incremental infrastructure improvements and investments at our utilities and funding the growth plans at our non-utility businesses.
Let me wrap up on Slide 16, and then can move to questions and answers. We've had a very good quarter as well as the first half of the year. We were able to raise our EPS guidance, setting us up nicely to send our streak to 10 consecutive years of meeting or exceeding our initial EPS guidance. This will be the seventh consecutive year that we've increased our dividend. This quarter, we announced coal plant retirements that will bring cleaner energy to our customers and considerable investment to our electric utility. Maintaining a strong balance sheet will allow us to invest in the utilities and pursue growth opportunities at our non-utility businesses.
Before I open up to Q&A, our call would not be complete without a quick update on my hometown Detroit Tigers. Now this -- the good news is that we won 50 games so far this year. The bad news is that we lost about as many games as well. Justin Verlander [ph] is looking better recently and actually won last night in Boston, but Miguel Cabrera [ph] [indiscernible] to heat up for us to have a chance. There's a lot of season left, so I'm remaining optimistic.
With that, I'd like to thank everyone for joining us this morning. So Steffie, you can open lines up for questions.

componenttext: Yes. The pipelines, the 1.5 BCF and the interconnect agreements are 1.75. Those interconnects are independent of what we already have contracted on the pipeline. Maybe I'll hand it over to Jerry Norcia to talk about the -- probably the process and timing for converting those to contracts.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Gerry. So right now, the pipe is 2/3 full. And the environment as we see it is starting to improve significantly in that region, in the production region that NEXUS serves or collects its gas from. So we're seeing renewed interest in terms o
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Gerry. So right now, the pipe is 2/3 full. And the environment as we see it is starting to improve significantly in that region, in the production region that NEXUS serves or collects its gas from. So we're seeing renewed interest in terms of discussions from the producers as well as we're progressing a series of conversations along the pipeline in Ohio and in Michigan and other markets, in Ontario as well as other parts of Midwest where customers are interested in subscribing [ph] for capacity. So we're confident that by the time the pipe goes into service, we would have more [indiscernible].

componenttext: Got it. Okay. And then my second question. Can you just generally comment on what's going on in the power and industrial segment. Is it seasonality? And then in the presentation, you commented on maybe some weaker steel offset by more positive REF earnings.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's 2 dynamics happening. One of them you mentioned was the seasonality that will occur with our REF units. Actually the first quarter we had a little bit lower volumes given the warm weather winter we're seeing actually reverse coming here in the sum
componenttext: There's 2 dynamics happening. One of them you mentioned was the seasonality that will occur with our REF units. Actually the first quarter we had a little bit lower volumes given the warm weather winter we're seeing actually reverse coming here in the summer with the hot weather we're experiencing. So there is back-end loading that will occur with our REF units. We did have some planned maintenance outages. We have wood waste renewable plant. So that those planned outages did occur this year in the second quarter. So there is seasonality related to those earnings as well for the planned maintenance outages. We came into the year understanding the depressed steel market. We put that in the plan, and the offset was the REF units and the volume related to REF, and that's playing out as designed.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: I guess one comment would be that just as in the E&P sector, you're beginning to feel the turn there. Same in steel. You're beginning to feel the turn in the steel sector. So I think it begins to bode well for '17 and '18 as that sector gets some wind behind it.

componenttext: It is. It is basically, all of that. You look at year-to-date results, year-over-year, the relatively flat. We knew going into the year, we were going to have a warm first quarter. That did play out, and we planned for the rest of the year to make it up. And the second quarter, the O&M levels, in particular, were down quite a bit that helped offset those first quarter earnings. One thing we're looking at right now, given the strength in our electric utility, and we always like to manage typically on a combined utility basis that we essentially will start investing back into the gas utilities and getting those O&M levels back to normal levels.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then lastly, is there anything going on behind the scenes in Lansing with regards to energy policy and legislation?
componenttext: And then lastly, is there anything going on behind the scenes in Lansing with regards to energy policy and legislation?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we continue to work this summer with some of the principals. I think what's likely come fall is that there will be activity again in the Senate. We kind of ran out of time there with all the dynamics in the legislator between plants and roads and Detro
componenttext: So we continue to work this summer with some of the principals. I think what's likely come fall is that there will be activity again in the Senate. We kind of ran out of time there with all the dynamics in the legislator between plants and roads and Detroit schools and things. So I think there will be activity in the Senate, and then there will be a chance that something could get passed in the Senate in the session in September, but we'll see. And then I think everybody will watch the election and see what the election dynamics mean for the Michigan legislator with the possibility that we would pick back up and pass legislation in the lame duck session at the end of the year. So if legislation is going to pass this year, it would be in the lame duck. I guess, I keep reminding folks that this is not so much a financial discussion. In fact, it's not a financial discussion. It really doesn't affect our 5-year plan, but it is an energy reliability discussion. And at some point or another, we need to get -- we need to be clear on who's building power plants for 10% of the market. And right now, the answer is nobody. And until we get policy in place that ensures that somebody does it, there's risk of reliability issues with the state. So if it doesn't happen this year, it will happen at some point when it becomes clear that we need to take care of that.

So we look forward to giving you another positive update in 3 months, and thanks very much for joining us this morning.
