componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the DTE Energy Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Barb Tuckfield. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tanisha, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the safe harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes refere
componenttext:
Thank you, Tanisha, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the safe harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes references to operating earnings, which is a non-GAAP financial measure. Please refer to the reconciliation of GAAP net income to operating income provided in the appendix of today's presentation. Peter Oleksiak, our Senior Vice President and CFO, will be providing a financial update for the third quarter of 2016 guidance. We also have members of the management team here that we can call on during the Q&A session. 
And now I'll turn it over to Peter to start the call.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Barb. Good morning to everyone, and thanks for joining us today. Of course you know DTE earnings call, we complete without an update on retires so let me get that over with here. As it's disappointing to say that over the second straight season, r
componenttext:
Thanks, Barb. Good morning to everyone, and thanks for joining us today. Of course you know DTE earnings call, we complete without an update on retires so let me get that over with here. As it's disappointing to say that over the second straight season, retires did not make the postseason. We really only saw this year that we were the last American team to be eliminated from contention this year but I do like to congratulate 2 great Midwestern cities, Cleveland and Chicago for being in the World Series. And as always, I look forward to a breaker season next year. 
Now for an update on DTE, we're keeping today's call focused on the quarter and the current year, and as you can see, I'm the only participant here. We have other members of management team here for the Q&A session, and I will call on them throughout the Q&A if needed. And I will also be deferring questions on long-term growth and strategy to the EI Conference, which is only a few weeks away. Gerry Anderson will be providing our normal detailed business update at EEI. There, he will discuss our 2017 early outlook and long-term growth plans as well as details about each of the business segments. So now I'd like to start on Slide 4.
As you know in September, we raised our operating EPS guidance for 2016. At that time, we increased the guidance midpoint $0.17 to a range of $5.09 to $5.35 from a range of $4.91 to $5.19. The guidance increases were driven by a lot of weather favorability at DTE Electric, favorability across all platforms at the gas storage and pipeline business and a strong year-to-date economic performance at our trading company.
In the past, we've talked about our reinvestment strategy, holding favorability until we see the summer months play out. While this summer was the hottest we've had in the past 60 years, and we're able to reap out a lot of those revenues back into the system into aging infrastructure to improve customer liability.
We've invested a nominal amount this quarter. We're stepping up our reinvestment activity for the remainder of the year. Investments will primarily be in our infrastructure with a focus on improving immediate and lasting benefits to our customers. 
Another area where we are seeing great results this year is in safety. Now we always start every meeting with a discussion on safety and it's our #1 priority in the company. And I'm particularly pleased to announce that the year-to-date, our employees continue to have the best safety record in the company's history. 
And of course, we have had a major announcement in our gas storage and pipeline segment in the third quarter with the acquisition of a gas midstream assets in the heart of the Southwest Marcellus and dry Utica basin. The transaction complements our existing midstream business and provides a platform for new value creation and significant growth opportunities. I will be discussing the growth opportunities and their impacts on our business at EEI. 
Now I'd like to go over the third quarter earning results on Slide 5. For the quarter, DTE's operating earnings were $353 million, or $1.96 per share. For reference, our reported earnings were $1.88 per share and you can find the reconciliation with the third quarter reported to operating earnings on Slide 17 of the appendix.  For the quarter, our growth segments operating earnings were $343 million, or $1.91 per share. 
Now starting with the segments, with DTE Electric, it was higher by $71 million. This quarter was as I indicated when the warmest on record and drove much of this favorability. DTE Electric also [indiscernible] a rate increase on August 1 as part of the ongoing rate case. This favorability was partially offset by increased expenses associated with the rate base growth. DTE Gas was higher by $7 million. This was primarily driven by gas, main line replacement surcharge and the storage and transport services. 
Our Power and Industrial Projects segments was higher by $3 million due primarily to higher REF earnings from additional location that came online in the fourth quarter of last year. These earnings were partially offset by lower earnings in our steel-related assets. Corporate and Other segment came in at $8 million favorable versus last year. This variance was mainly due to timing of taxes. Again, overall, the growth segment results for the quarter were $343 million, or $1.91 per share. 
Following with our Energy Trading segment, there were $10 million in operating earnings for the quarter and economic net income was $1 million. Please refer to Slide 15 of the appendix, which shows our standard view of the Energy Trading reconciliation of both economic and operating performance. So overall, DTE had a very strong third quarter. 
With that, moving on to Slide 6. I'd like to provide an update on our 2016 earnings guidance. As I mentioned, we recently raised 2016 guidance and are confident that we will land somewhere between the midpoint and upper end of our guidance this year. Year-to-date results are solid and we are in good position to finish the year strong. You can see arrows next to each of the guidance numbers in akin where we think the year may play out for each segment. The green arrows indicate achieving the higher end of guidance while the red arrows signifies the lower end. The positive signaling at DTE Electric is driven by additional weather experienced at September. We had a very warm September. Our corporate and Other segment is trending towards the lower end of guidance driven by our tax true-ups. 
In the fourth quarter, we expect Energy Trading to have accounting income that covers our expenses, which puts them at the high-end of the guidance range. 
Now moving on to Slide 7. In addition to the solid earnings results, our cash flow and balance sheet are strong and continues to support a long-term growth. Based on year-to-date results, we are updating our cash flow and capital expenditure guidance, starting at the left side of the page, we're increasing cash from operations by $200 million due to the strong cash performance year-to-date. CapEx is increasing by $1.1 billion, which is primarily due to the recent acquisition of our gas midstream assets. We're also increasing our debt financing by $900 million, which was used in part for recent our acquisition and also for general corporate uses. 
Taking a closer look at CapEx on the right side of the page, we show capital expenditure by business units. We still expect to invest nearly $1.6 billion at the electric company and $430 million at the gas company. We have increased the nonutility guidance by $1.1 billion, the exchanges I mentioned capture the purchase of the gas midstream assets. This brings our total capital expenditures to nearly $3.8 billion for the year.
Now let's move on to Slide 8 with a look at our balance sheet metrics. Our balance sheet remains strong. We expect to end the year within our targeted range for both leverage and FFO to debt. Due to the strong year-to-date earnings and cash flow, we will not be issuing equity in 2016. In early October, DTE issued $1 billion of senior notes and $675 million of mandatory convertible securities to support the midstream acquisition. As a reminder, the $675 million of mandatory convertible securities will convert to common equity in October of 2019. 
Lastly, we ended the quarter with very healthy liquidity position of $1.6 billion. Now wrapping up on Slide 9, I will summarize the quarter then open the line for questions. We've had another successful quarter and are in a great position to achieve our EPS guidance this year. We are looking to extend our street to 10 consecutive years of meeting or exceeding our initial EPS guidance. We are investing heavily in our utilities by upgrading our aging infrastructure, and we are executing on growth opportunities at our nonutility businesses, most notably, the gas storage and pipeline business, where we recently added a new platform for future growth. We continue to maintain a strong balance sheet, which sets up nicely for future growth opportunities as we enter a period of significant investment and begin to transform our electric generation fleet. 
Before I open the line for questions, once again, I'd like to remind everyone that Gerry Anderson will be giving our formal business update presentation at the upcoming EEI Conference on November 8, and we hope to see many of you at the conference. But if you can't make it in person, you can visit our Investor Relations website to listen in on the webcast. 
Now I'd like to open up for questions. So Tunisia, please open the line.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on Michigan legislation. There was a story in the press talking about some kind of breakthrough and expectation that this will get taken up after the election. But it wasn't clear from that, what exactly might have changed in the bill. Can
componenttext: My question is on Michigan legislation. There was a story in the press talking about some kind of breakthrough and expectation that this will get taken up after the election. But it wasn't clear from that, what exactly might have changed in the bill. Can you give any insight as to how you guys see this playing out and what there might be new to report?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of playing out, there is definitely a strong push to get this legislation done in lame duck. There's a lot of public communication that's happening out there. Senator Nofs has made this a priority for that. It is going to be a challenge potential
componenttext: In terms of playing out, there is definitely a strong push to get this legislation done in lame duck. There's a lot of public communication that's happening out there. Senator Nofs has made this a priority for that. It is going to be a challenge potentially given the time frame left but I think given the focus and attention on that, there's still a chance it will happen in the lame-duck session. We have had some public support recently. The Michigan State Chamber came out publicly to support this bill so I think that's a very positive movement as well. In terms of what has changed is that, this bill in particular, is going to be a bipartisan bill. It is related to the state of Michigan, the energy reliability that's needed in the state of Michigan. So both parties need to be supportive and both parties want to get this energy legislation passed. So recently, there was some discussion on the renewable side potentially for that mandate, clearly, we're at 10%, potentially go up to 15%. That will help get some of the Democrats onboard as well and some of the refining, as I was mentioning even when I've been on the road, that some of it is -- getting the detailed road around the retail open access and the capacity requirements related to that. So there is some finalization around that language. I know there is a new MISO tariff that may be out there as well that's going to help support and complement legislation as well.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the strong quarter from the weather, I was just wondering if you could just comment on how that will affect the O&M in the fourth quarter and your lean in initiatives?
componenttext: With the strong quarter from the weather, I was just wondering if you could just comment on how that will affect the O&M in the fourth quarter and your lean in initiatives?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. With all this favorability, we are going to be putting some of that back into the business. And we've done this periodically as you know. And this really helps maintain long-term really good operations. And we would like to put it into a customer-cen
componenttext: Yes. With all this favorability, we are going to be putting some of that back into the business. And we've done this periodically as you know. And this really helps maintain long-term really good operations. And we would like to put it into a customer-centric type of assets and infrastructure assets. So we are targeting potentially around $20 million of aftertax and the vast majority of that will happen in the fourth quarter. We had a minimal amount that did occur here in the third quarter.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to follow-up on NEXUS as we await the, I think, to draft the EIS or the final EIS at this point, right?
componenttext: And just to follow-up on NEXUS as we await the, I think, to draft the EIS or the final EIS at this point, right?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. An overall update, I can give you an overall update on NEXUS. Now we are really at this point, in the late stage. Constructions, once again, we are very positive on this project. It's going to be a real strategic part of our portfolio. So late stage
componenttext: Yes. An overall update, I can give you an overall update on NEXUS. Now we are really at this point, in the late stage. Constructions, once again, we are very positive on this project. It's going to be a real strategic part of our portfolio. So late stage construction the pipe is being fabricated as we speak. Another great milestone here is that we recently signed in the first half an interconnect agreement in Ohio with an LDC. We have 1.75 of tap and interconnect agreements, and we expect to term some of those out, and that's how we're expecting to help build out the pipe. We are currently at the 2/3, and now we've been at the 2/3 for a little bit here. Some of that is with the E&P companies taking a pause with their balance sheets, but we're starting to get some express interest with the E&P companies. But I do expect a good portion to remain in pipe being filled -- will be being filled potentially within that Ohio market. We expect to receive the final environmental impact next month with the final certificate in the first quarter of 2017 commence construction, and still targeting the fourth quarter of 2017 in service.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The improvement in natural gas prices and frac spreads, I'm just wondering if you're seeing increased amount of interest in the pipeline at all.
componenttext: The improvement in natural gas prices and frac spreads, I'm just wondering if you're seeing increased amount of interest in the pipeline at all.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are and there has always been a lot of interest, a lot of the pause, it's just with the E&P companies getting, first getting their balance sheets in order, and the other is coming up with the new capital plans and drilling plans. And there is going to
componenttext: We are and there has always been a lot of interest, a lot of the pause, it's just with the E&P companies getting, first getting their balance sheets in order, and the other is coming up with the new capital plans and drilling plans. And there is going to be a focus on this region in particular, the Utica and Marcellus, so a lot of the -- a lot of that to some internal processing that needed to happen within the E&P companies. The other benefit is we do have, with the new acquisitions, there are some synergies potentially there as well that can help support the NEXUS Pipeline.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So perhaps just follow-up on the last couple of questions. First, you kind of alluded to already but the deal with MISOs, the MPSC and the governor's office as well. Can you comment a little bit on how that fits within what you're trying to achieve with t
componenttext: So perhaps just follow-up on the last couple of questions. First, you kind of alluded to already but the deal with MISOs, the MPSC and the governor's office as well. Can you comment a little bit on how that fits within what you're trying to achieve with the legislation? Is that also one of the reasons why you've been able to get some progress? And can you comment on the path forward on the timing and what you expect that to look like, ultimately, or how it complements?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of comments on that. I think that the movement with the governor and with MISO and the MPSC really shows that this issue really is around electric reliability in the state of Michigan. So this was kind of a potential, how do we ensure some reliab
componenttext: A couple of comments on that. I think that the movement with the governor and with MISO and the MPSC really shows that this issue really is around electric reliability in the state of Michigan. So this was kind of a potential, how do we ensure some reliability and capacity in the state of Michigan. It does help complement legislation, so that will be 1 where we'll have the requirements for the retail open access providers and show what's your capacity plans. And with a lot of the local clearing requirements, they'll have to be in place given the fact that -- given the Peninsula state that we have, the limited amount of transmission, we need to have a lot of local generation. So this new tariff, if the ROA customers cannot get the capacity, they'll come to the utilities, and we've provided with a capacity surcharge. My understanding is MISO will be filing this new tariff with the FERC shortly potentially next month.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. To what extent does that achieve your goals around ROA, I mean, I suppose in part, getting paid for the capacity? I suppose you're moving forward to the new gas pipeline, so that shows some amount of confidence in the underlying regulatory constru
componenttext: Got it. To what extent does that achieve your goals around ROA, I mean, I suppose in part, getting paid for the capacity? I suppose you're moving forward to the new gas pipeline, so that shows some amount of confidence in the underlying regulatory constructed presence? I don't want to mix issues here too much, though.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The goal for the retail open access was first is to make sure that they have capacity within the state of Michigan, that we have reliability in the state of Michigan and that's the #1 concern with that for the policy and the regulators and this really doe
componenttext: The goal for the retail open access was first is to make sure that they have capacity within the state of Michigan, that we have reliability in the state of Michigan and that's the #1 concern with that for the policy and the regulators and this really does help ensure whether they got to get it themselves, if not, they get to turn to us, and we've got to make sure we get it for them.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then turning back to Mike's question a second ago. Can you talk a little bit about -- obviously, there are some multiple adjacent projects going forward, it seems like you guys obviously are moving forward with your project irrespective. Is th
componenttext: Got it. And then turning back to Mike's question a second ago. Can you talk a little bit about -- obviously, there are some multiple adjacent projects going forward, it seems like you guys obviously are moving forward with your project irrespective. Is there an ability to combine projects and/or are you seeing or having conversations with the offtake that have strung in some of the projects thus far? I'm just kind of curious if you're seeing some cannibalization here.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I can say that we definitely like our pipe where it's at. We provide a northern path and E&P companies are looking to get their product to market as they like to diversify where they're putting it. So putting it north within the markets of Ohio, Michi
componenttext: No. I can say that we definitely like our pipe where it's at. We provide a northern path and E&P companies are looking to get their product to market as they like to diversify where they're putting it. So putting it north within the markets of Ohio, Michigan and Ontario definitely helps. And so we're really at this point, concentrating on our project. I think a lot of the interest in our project is just because of the multiple markets that it serves. So we're continuing to see a lot of interest in our projects and we're not really kind of worried about other projects in the area, and we're really -- we have a great project. We think we do have the best northern path at this point in time.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Got it, but not taking contracts or in discussions with the actual operators and the other ones by any means?

componenttext: No, we were in contract -- I mean in good discussions with E&P companies around the NEXUS Pipeline and if they want to get their product north, they're in discussions with us.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: With your recent acquisition at storage and pipes, are you kind of rightsized, or do you think you have this potential other opportunities out there?
componenttext: With your recent acquisition at storage and pipes, are you kind of rightsized, or do you think you have this potential other opportunities out there?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point in time, if that's really around new acquisitions, I would say, we are not looking for a new -- make acquisitions of this size. We like to develop pipes traditionally, greenfield, that's where you get your most value creation. There is a uni
componenttext: At this point in time, if that's really around new acquisitions, I would say, we are not looking for a new -- make acquisitions of this size. We like to develop pipes traditionally, greenfield, that's where you get your most value creation. There is a unique opportunity here. There is a great pipe in the regions that we want to be in, which is the Utica Marcellus, 40% of the gas, and the country is going to be delivered from this region. It also fits within our footprint and potentially help support the NEXUS Pipeline. So at this point in time, we are looking at developing multiple pipe platforms, growth platforms or NEXUS platform, and obviously, we'll be putting a lot of push and development on that. And then this pipeline in particular, there's a lot of upside potential given the expansion opportunities here and some new greenfield around the pipe that has yet to be drilled and put into the pipes. I'd say it's -- we're going to be -- the focus will be on the development of this pipe. There may be some smaller bolt-on type of acquisitions potentially. So we're comfortable right now with the growth platforms that we have in place and the development opportunities around them.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: I know Mike Nofs has been working both in the Senate but also the House in particular. So I think that some of the movement you're seeing with the renewable died in the mandate. That's going to help get support within the House. So it's still kind of a wait-and-see to see if they can get it through the Senate and the House. There will be postelection. The idea is potentially to not get it through the Senate, and then after Thanksgiving, work it through the House. So if there's enough support within the Senate, and then we get enough of the House Democrats, there is a chance that it can get it done this year.

componenttext: Okay. And the just finally, back to the MISO capacity proposal. What I'm wondering is, would this still be a wholesale transaction that the alternative energy provider would be charged? I mean in other words, would they have to pay you the capacity fee or -- because that's a little bit confused by jurisdictionally. When I read this proposal, it sounded like they could either buy capacity themselves or they could buy it from you at some set price by the Michigan PSE. And I'm wondering, will that be considered a wholesale transaction?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This really is getting at the issue that we need to have a very high local clearing requirement, which means in state generation. And either they can get generation within the state themselves, if they can't, they can procure it from us. And we need to be
componenttext: This really is getting at the issue that we need to have a very high local clearing requirement, which means in state generation. And either they can get generation within the state themselves, if they can't, they can procure it from us. And we need to be compensated for those and it would be a capacity charge put in place and the publisher was commissioned would be kind of over that capacity charge and what the amount would be.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Would FERC have to be -- they're involved in this, and so far it's a wholesale transaction, to alter that the Michigan PSE would be setting the price for, do you follow what I'm saying?

componenttext: No. The FERC would not be involved.

componenttext: Our high-level timeline on that, Gregg is next year, probably late next year, we'll be providing -- we'll be filing a certificate of need around that with the air permitting, everything that we would need to get the projects going. The spending on that will occur at the back end of this 5-year plan. The in-service date that we put within the recent press MISO is 2021 to 2023 time frame. So spending will be occurring within a few years. So probably, shortly after that, that certificate of need, probably within a year after that, there'll be some spending occuring, actually spending a little bit of spending before that just to prepare for the certificate of need.

componenttext: Really, it is a function. We have a clear path, contiguous pathway with that, with our system that we purchased. With the Texas Eastern Pipeline, there's capacity that we've contracted out NEXUS at, to get it to NEXUS. So it really is around the producers, the drilling plants around those producers, potentially not signing up new producers by getting the drilling plans with the existing producers we have on that pipe and the new assets that we purchased.

componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the DTE Energy Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Barb Tuckfield. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tanisha, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the safe harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes refere
componenttext:
Thank you, Tanisha, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the safe harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes references to operating earnings, which is a non-GAAP financial measure. Please refer to the reconciliation of GAAP net income to operating income provided in the appendix of today's presentation. Peter Oleksiak, our Senior Vice President and CFO, will be providing a financial update for the third quarter of 2016 guidance. We also have members of the management team here that we can call on during the Q&A session. 
And now I'll turn it over to Peter to start the call.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Barb. Good morning to everyone, and thanks for joining us today. Of course, no DTE earnings call would be complete without an update on my Tigers, so let me get that over with here. As it's disappointing to say that over the second straight season
componenttext:
Thanks, Barb. Good morning to everyone, and thanks for joining us today. Of course, no DTE earnings call would be complete without an update on my Tigers, so let me get that over with here. As it's disappointing to say that over the second straight season, the Tigers did not make the postseason. Really, the only solace here is that we were the last American team to be eliminated from contention this year, but I do like to congratulate 2 great Midwestern cities, Cleveland and Chicago, for being in the World Series. And as always, I'll look forward to a brighter season next year. 
Now for an update on DTE, we're keeping today's call focused on the quarter and the current year, and as you can see, I'm the only participant here. We have other members of management team here for the Q&A session, and I will call on them throughout the Q&A, if needed. And I will also be deferring questions on long-term growth and strategy to the EI Conference, which is only a few weeks away. Gerry Anderson will be providing our normal detailed business update at EEI. There, he will discuss our 2017 early outlook and long-term growth plans as well as details about each of the business segments. So now I'd like to start on Slide 4.
As you know in September, we raised our operating EPS guidance for 2016. At that time, we increased the guidance midpoint $0.17 to a range of $5.09 to $5.35 from a range of $4.91 to $5.19. The guidance increases were driven by a lot of weather favorability at DTE Electric, favorability across all platforms at the gas storage and pipeline business and a strong year-to-date economic performance at our trading company.
In the past, we've talked about our reinvestment strategy, holding favorability until we see the summer months play out. Well, this summer was the hottest we've had in the past 60 years, and we were able to reinvest a lot of those revenues back into the system into aging infrastructure to improve customer liability.
We've invested a nominal amount this quarter. We're stepping up our reinvestment activity for the remainder of the year. Investments will primarily be in our infrastructure, with a focus on improving immediate and lasting benefits to our customers. 
Another area where we are seeing great results this year is in safety. Now we always start every meeting with a discussion on safety and it's our #1 priority in the company. And I'm particularly pleased to announce that year-to-date, our employees continue to have the best safety record in the company's history. 
And of course, we have had a major announcement in our gas storage and pipeline segment in the third quarter with the acquisition of a gas midstream assets in the heart of the Southwest Marcellus and dry Utica basin. The transaction complements our existing midstream business and provides a platform for new value creation and significant growth opportunities. I will be discussing the growth opportunities and their impact on our business at EEI. 
Now I'd like to go over the third quarter earning results on Slide 5. For the quarter, DTE's operating earnings were $353 million, or $1.96 per share. For reference, our reported earnings were $1.88 per share and you can find a reconciliation with the third quarter reported operating earnings on Slide 17 of the appendix. For the quarter, our growth segments operating earnings were $343 million, or $1.91 per share. 
Now starting with the segments, with DTE Electric, it was higher by $71 million. This quarter was, as I indicated, when the warmest on record and drove much of this favorability. DTE Electric also supplemented a rate increase on August 1 as part of the ongoing rate case. This favorability was partially offset by increased expenses associated with the rate base growth. DTE Gas was higher by $7 million. This was primarily driven by gas, main line replacement surcharge and the storage and transport services. 
Our Power and Industrial Projects segments was higher by $3 million due primarily to higher REF earnings from additional location that came online in the fourth quarter of last year. These earnings were partially offset by lower earnings in our steel-related assets. Our Corporate and Other segment came in at $8 million favorable versus last year. This variance was mainly due to timing of taxes. Again, overall, the growth segment results for the quarter were $343 million, or $1.91 per share. 
Following with our Energy Trading segment, there were $10 million in operating earnings for the quarter and economic net income was $1 million. Please refer to Slide 15 in the appendix, which shows our standard view of the Energy Trading reconciliation of both economic and operating performance. So overall, DTE had a very strong third quarter. 
With that, moving on to Slide 6. I'd like to provide an update on our 2016 earnings guidance. As I mentioned, we recently raised 2016 guidance and are confident that we will land somewhere between the midpoint and upper end of our guidance this year. Year-to-date results are solid, and we are in good position to finish the year strong. You can see arrows next to each of the guidance numbers indicating where we think the year may play out for each segment. The green arrows indicate achieving the higher end of guidance, while the red arrows signifies the lower end. The positive signaling at DTE Electric is driven by additional weather experienced at the end of September. We had a very warm September. Our corporate and Other segment is trending towards the lower end of guidance driven by our tax true-ups. 
In the fourth quarter, we expect Energy Trading to have accounting income that covers their expenses, which puts them at the high-end of the guidance range. 
Now moving on to Slide 7. In addition to the solid earnings results, our cash flow and balance sheet are strong and continue to support a long-term growth. Based on year-to-date results, we are updating our cash flow and capital expenditure guidance. Starting at the left side of the page, we're increasing cash from operations by $200 million due to the strong cash performance year-to-date. CapEx is increasing by $1.1 billion, which is primarily due to the recent acquisition of our gas midstream assets. We're also increasing our debt financing by $900 million, which was used in part for a recent our acquisition and also for general corporate uses. 
Taking a closer look at CapEx, on the right side of the page, we show capital expenditure by business units. We still expect to invest nearly $1.6 billion at the electric company and $430 million at the gas company. We have increased the nonutility guidance by $1.1 billion. This exchange, as I mentioned, captured the purchase of the gas midstream assets. This brings our total capital expenditures to nearly $3.8 billion for the year.
Now let's move on to Slide 8, with a look at our balance sheet metrics. Our balance sheet remains strong. We expect to end the year within our targeted range for both leverage and FFO to debt. Due to the strong year-to-date earnings and cash flow, we will not be issuing equity in 2016. In early October, DTE issued $1 billion of senior notes and $675 million of mandatory convertible securities to support the midstream acquisition. As a reminder, the $675 million of mandatory convertible securities will convert to common equity in October of 2019. 
Lastly, we ended the quarter with a very healthy liquidity position of $1.6 billion. Now wrapping up on Slide 9, I will summarize the quarter, then open the line for questions. We've had another successful quarter and are in a great position to achieve our EPS guidance this year. We are looking to extend our streak to 10 consecutive years of meeting or exceeding our initial EPS guidance. We are investing heavily in our utilities by upgrading our aging infrastructure, and we are executing on growth opportunities at our nonutility businesses, most notably, the gas storage and pipeline business, where we recently added a new platform for future growth. We continue to maintain a strong balance sheet, which sets up nicely for future growth opportunities as we enter a period of significant investment and begin to transform our electric generation fleet. 
Before I open the line for questions, once again, I'd like to remind everyone that Gerry Anderson will be giving our formal business update presentation at the upcoming EEI Conference on November 8, and we hope to see many of you at the conference. But if you can't make it in person, you can visit our Investor Relations website to listen in on the webcast. 
Now I'd like to open up for questions. So, Tanisha, please open the line.

componenttext: Yes.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on Michigan legislation. There was a story in the press talking about some kind of breakthrough and expectation that this will get taken up after the election. But it wasn't clear from that what exactly might have changed in the bill. Can y
componenttext: My question is on Michigan legislation. There was a story in the press talking about some kind of breakthrough and expectation that this will get taken up after the election. But it wasn't clear from that what exactly might have changed in the bill. Can you give any insight as to how you guys see this playing out and what there might be new to report?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of playing out, there is definitely a strong push to get this legislation done in lame duck. There's a lot of public communication that's happening out there. Senator Nofs has made this a priority for that. It is going to be a challenge pote
componenttext: Yes, in terms of playing out, there is definitely a strong push to get this legislation done in lame duck. There's a lot of public communication that's happening out there. Senator Nofs has made this a priority for that. It is going to be a challenge potentially, given the time frame left. But I think given the focus and attention on that, there's still a chance it will happen in the lame-duck session. We have had some public support recently. The Michigan State Chamber came out publicly to support this bill so I think that's a very positive movement as well. In terms of what has changed is that, this bill in particular, is going to be a bipartisan bill. It is related to the state of Michigan, the energy reliability that's needed in the state of Michigan. So both parties need to be supportive and both parties want to get this energy legislation passed. So recently, there is some discussion on the renewable side potentially for that mandate,. Currently, we're at 10%. Potentially, it will go up to 15%. That will help get some of the Democrats onboard as well. And some of the refining, as I was mentioning even when I've been on the road, that some of it is -- getting the details right around the retail open access and the capacity requirements related to that, so there is some finalization around that language. I know there is a new MISO tariff that may be out there as well that's going to help support and complement legislation as well.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes. With all this favorability, we are going to be putting some of that back into the business. And we've done this periodically, as you know. And this really helps maintain long-term really good operations. And we would like to put it into a customer-centric type of assets and infrastructure assets. So we are targeting potentially around $20 million of aftertax and the vast majority of that will happen in the fourth quarter. We had a minimal amount that did occur here in the third quarter.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to follow-up on NEXUS as we await the, I think, to draft the EIS or the final EIS at this point, right?
componenttext: And just to follow-up on NEXUS as we await the, I think, to draft the EIS or the final EIS at this point, right?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. An overall update, I can give you an overall update on NEXUS. Now we are really at this point, in the late stage of construction. Once again, we are very positive on this project. It's going to be a real strategic part of our portfolio. So late-stage
componenttext: Yes. An overall update, I can give you an overall update on NEXUS. Now we are really at this point, in the late stage of construction. Once again, we are very positive on this project. It's going to be a real strategic part of our portfolio. So late-stage construction the pipe is being fabricated as we speak. Another great milestone here is that we recently signed in the first half an interconnect agreement in Ohio with an LDC. We have 1.75 of tap and interconnect agreements, and we expect to term some of those out, and that's how we're expecting to help build out the pipe. We are currently at the 2/3, and now we've been at the 2/3 for a little bit here. Some of that is with the E&P companies taking a pause with their balance sheets, but we're starting to get some express interest with the E&P companies. But I do expect a good portion of the remaining pipe being filled will be being filled potentially within that Ohio market. We expect to receive the final environmental impact next month, with the final certificate in the first quarter of 2017. Commenced construction and still targeting the fourth quarter of 2017 in service.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The improvement in natural gas prices and frac spreads, I'm just wondering if you're seeing increased amount of interest in the pipeline at all.
componenttext: The improvement in natural gas prices and frac spreads, I'm just wondering if you're seeing increased amount of interest in the pipeline at all.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are, and there has always been a lot of interest, a lot of the pause is just with the E&P companies getting, first getting their balance sheets in order, and the other is coming up with the new capital plans and drilling plans. And there is going to be
componenttext: We are, and there has always been a lot of interest, a lot of the pause is just with the E&P companies getting, first getting their balance sheets in order, and the other is coming up with the new capital plans and drilling plans. And there is going to be a focus on this region in particular, the Utica and Marcellus, so a lot of the -- a lot of that is some internal processing that needed to happen within the E&P companies. The other benefit is we do have, with the new acquisitions, there are some synergies potentially there as well that can help support the NEXUS Pipeline.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Julien Dumoulin-Smith with UBS.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So perhaps just to follow up on the last couple of questions. First, you kind of alluded to already but the deal with MISOs, the MPSC and the governor's office as well. Can you comment a little bit on how that fits within what you're trying to achieve wit
componenttext: So perhaps just to follow up on the last couple of questions. First, you kind of alluded to already but the deal with MISOs, the MPSC and the governor's office as well. Can you comment a little bit on how that fits within what you're trying to achieve with the legislation? Is that also one of the reasons why you've been able to get some progress? And can you comment on the path forward on the timing and what you expect that to look like, ultimately, or how it complements?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of comments on that. I think that the movement with the governor and with MISO and the MPSC really shows that this issue really is around electric reliability in the state of Michigan. So this was kind of a potential how do we ensure some reliabi
componenttext: A couple of comments on that. I think that the movement with the governor and with MISO and the MPSC really shows that this issue really is around electric reliability in the state of Michigan. So this was kind of a potential how do we ensure some reliability and capacity in the state of Michigan. It does help complement legislation, so that will be one where we'll have the requirements for the retail open access providers and show what's your capacity plans. And with a lot of the local clearing requirements, they'll have to be in place given the fact that -- given the Peninsula state that we have, the limited amount of transmission, we need to have a lot of local generation. So this new tariff, if the ROA customers cannot get the capacity, they'll come to the utilities, and we'll provided them with a capacity surcharge. My understanding is MISO will be filing this new tariff with the FERC shortly, potentially next month.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. To what extent does that achieve your goals around ROA? I mean, I suppose in part, getting paid for the capacity. I suppose you're moving forward to the new gas pipeline, so that shows some amount of confidence in the underlying regulatory constru
componenttext: Got it. To what extent does that achieve your goals around ROA? I mean, I suppose in part, getting paid for the capacity. I suppose you're moving forward to the new gas pipeline, so that shows some amount of confidence in the underlying regulatory construct at presence? I don't want to mix issues here too much, though.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: The goal for the retail open access was first is to make sure that they have capacity within the state of Michigan, that we have reliability in the state of Michigan and that's the #1 concern with that for the policy and the regulators and this really doe
componenttext: The goal for the retail open access was first is to make sure that they have capacity within the state of Michigan, that we have reliability in the state of Michigan and that's the #1 concern with that for the policy and the regulators and this really does help ensure it, whether they got to get it themselves, if not, now they've got to turn to us and we've got to make sure we get it for them.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then turning back to Mike's question a second ago. Can you cover a little bit about -- obviously, there are some multiple adjacent projects going forward, it seems like you guys obviously are moving forward with your project irrespective. Is t
componenttext: Got it. And then turning back to Mike's question a second ago. Can you cover a little bit about -- obviously, there are some multiple adjacent projects going forward, it seems like you guys obviously are moving forward with your project irrespective. Is there an ability to combine projects and/or are you seeing or having conversations with the offtakers from some of the other projects thus far? I'm just kind of curious if you're seeing some cannibalization here.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I can say that we definitely like our pipe where it's at. We provide a northern path. As E&P companies are looking to get their product to market as -- they like to diversify where they're putting it. So putting it north within the markets of Ohio, Mi
componenttext: No. I can say that we definitely like our pipe where it's at. We provide a northern path. As E&P companies are looking to get their product to market as -- they like to diversify where they're putting it. So putting it north within the markets of Ohio, Michigan and Ontario definitely helps. And so we're really, at this point, concentrating on our project. I think a lot of the interest in our project is just because of the multiple markets that it serves. So we're continuing to see a lot of interest in our projects and we're not really kind of worried about other projects in the area. We're really -- we have a great project. We think we do have the best northern path at this point in time.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, but not taking contracts or in discussions with the actual operators of the other ones by any means?
componenttext: Got it, but not taking contracts or in discussions with the actual operators of the other ones by any means?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we were in contract -- I mean, in good discussions with E&P companies around the NEXUS Pipeline and if they want to get their product north, they're in discussions with us.
componenttext: No, we were in contract -- I mean, in good discussions with E&P companies around the NEXUS Pipeline and if they want to get their product north, they're in discussions with us.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: With your recent acquisition at storage and pipes, are you kind of rightsized, or do you think you -- there's potential other opportunities out there?
componenttext: With your recent acquisition at storage and pipes, are you kind of rightsized, or do you think you -- there's potential other opportunities out there?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this point in time, if that's really around new acquisitions, I would say, we are not looking for a new -- make acquisitions of this size. We like to develop pipes traditionally, greenfield, that's where you get your most value creation. There is a uni
componenttext: At this point in time, if that's really around new acquisitions, I would say, we are not looking for a new -- make acquisitions of this size. We like to develop pipes traditionally, greenfield, that's where you get your most value creation. There is a unique opportunity here. There is a great pipe in the regions that we want to be in, which is the Utica Marcellus. 40% of the gas in the country is going to be delivered from this region. It also fits within our footprint and potentially help support the NEXUS Pipeline. So at this point in time, we are looking at developing multiple pipe platforms, growth platforms, our NEXUS platform, and obviously, we'll be putting a lot of push and development on that. And then in this pipeline in particular, there's a lot of upside potential given the expansion opportunities here and some new greenfield around the pipe that has yet to be drilled and put into the pipes. I'd say it's -- we're going to be -- the focus will be on the development of this pipe. There may be some smaller bolt-on type of acquisitions potentially. So we're comfortable right now with the growth platforms that we have in place and the development opportunities around them.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: I know Mike Nofs has been working both in the Senate but also the House in particular. So I think that some of the movement you're seeing with the renewable died in the mandate. That's going to help get support within the House. So it's still kind of a wait-and-see to see if they can get it through the Senate and the House. There will be postelection, the idea is potentially to get it through the Senate, and then after Thanksgiving, work it through the House. So if there's enough support within the Senate, and then we get enough of the House Democrats, there is a chance that it can get done this year.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the just finally, back to the MISO capacity proposal. What I'm wondering is, would this still be a wholesale transaction that the alternative energy provider would be charged? I mean, in other words, would they have to pay you a capacity fee or
componenttext: Okay. And the just finally, back to the MISO capacity proposal. What I'm wondering is, would this still be a wholesale transaction that the alternative energy provider would be charged? I mean, in other words, would they have to pay you a capacity fee or -- because that's why I was a little bit confused by jurisdictionally. When I read this proposal, it sounded like they could either buy capacity themselves or they could buy it from you at some set price by the Michigan PSE. And I'm wondering, would that be considered a wholesale transaction?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: This really is getting at the issue that we need to have a very high local clearing requirement, which means in-state generation. And either they can get generation within the state themselves; if they can't, they can procure it from us. And we need to be
componenttext: This really is getting at the issue that we need to have a very high local clearing requirement, which means in-state generation. And either they can get generation within the state themselves; if they can't, they can procure it from us. And we need to be compensated for those and it would be a capacity charge put in place and the public service commission would be kind of over that capacity charge and what the amount would be.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would FERC have to be, though, involved in this, and so far it's a wholesale transaction, to alter that the Michigan PSE would be setting the price for, do you follow what I'm saying?
componenttext: Would FERC have to be, though, involved in this, and so far it's a wholesale transaction, to alter that the Michigan PSE would be setting the price for, do you follow what I'm saying?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. The FERC would not be involved.
componenttext: No. The FERC would not be involved.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Gregg Orrill with Barclays.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: You talked about in your release and previously, about building 1,000 megawatts of gas in Michigan for, I think it was, 2021. When do you expect to start spending there? And what needs to be done to move forward regulatorily or otherwise?
componenttext: You talked about in your release and previously, about building 1,000 megawatts of gas in Michigan for, I think it was, 2021. When do you expect to start spending there? And what needs to be done to move forward regulatorily or otherwise?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: A high-level comment on that, Gregg is next year, by late next year, we'll be providing -- we'll be filing a certificate of need around that with the air permitting, everything that we would need to get the projects going. The spending on that will occur
componenttext: A high-level comment on that, Gregg is next year, by late next year, we'll be providing -- we'll be filing a certificate of need around that with the air permitting, everything that we would need to get the projects going. The spending on that will occur at the back end of this 5-year plan. The in-service date that we put within the recent press MISO is 2021 to 2023 time frame. So spending will be occurring within a few years. So probably shortly after that, that certificate of need, probably within a year after that, there'll be some spending occurring. Actually spending -- a little bit of spending before that just to prepare for the certificate of need.

componenttext: And do you need to file for approval there?

componenttext: We would have to file a -- with our certificate of need process with our public service commission.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from Shahriar Pourreza with Guggenheim Partners.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one quick question on the synergies that you just mentioned around NEXUS and the GNP system that you purchased. But -- I know you will obviously disclose more when you get into EEI, but our synergies when you highlighted that, is that more of a funct
componenttext: Just one quick question on the synergies that you just mentioned around NEXUS and the GNP system that you purchased. But -- I know you will obviously disclose more when you get into EEI, but our synergies when you highlighted that, is that more of a function of adding additional producers to the pipe?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, it is a function. We have a clear path, contiguous pathway, with that, with our system that we purchased, with the Texas Eastern Pipeline, there's capacity that we've contracted out NEXUS at, to get it to NEXUS. So it really is around the producer
componenttext: Really, it is a function. We have a clear path, contiguous pathway, with that, with our system that we purchased, with the Texas Eastern Pipeline, there's capacity that we've contracted out NEXUS at, to get it to NEXUS. So it really is around the producers, the drilling plans around those producers, potentially not signing up new producers by getting the drilling plans with the existing producers we have on that pipe and the new assets that we purchased.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

Good day, and welcome to the DTE Energy Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Conference Call. Today's conference is being recorded. 
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Barb Tuckfield. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tanisha, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the safe harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes refere
componenttext:
Thank you, Tanisha, and good morning, everyone. Before we get started, I would like to remind you to read the safe harbor statement on Page 2 of the presentation, including the reference to forward-looking statements. Our presentation also includes references to operating earnings, which is a non-GAAP financial measure. Please refer to the reconciliation of GAAP net income to operating income provided in the appendix of today's presentation. Peter Oleksiak, our Senior Vice President and CFO, will be providing a financial update for the third quarter of 2016 guidance. We also have members of the management team here that we can call on during the Q&A session. 
And now I'll turn it over to Peter to start the call.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Barb. Good morning to everyone, and thanks for joining us today. Of course, no DTE earnings call would be complete without an update on my Tigers, so let me get that over with here. As it's disappointing to say that over the second straight season
componenttext:
Thanks, Barb. Good morning to everyone, and thanks for joining us today. Of course, no DTE earnings call would be complete without an update on my Tigers, so let me get that over with here. As it's disappointing to say that over the second straight season, the Tigers did not make the postseason. Really, the only solace here is that we were the last American team to be eliminated from contention this year, but I do like to congratulate 2 great Midwestern cities, Cleveland and Chicago, for being in the World Series. And as always, I'll look forward to a brighter season next year. 
Now for an update on DTE, we're keeping today's call focused on the quarter and the current year, and as you can see, I'm the only participant here. We have other members of management team here for the Q&A session, and I will call on them throughout the Q&A, if needed. And I will also be deferring questions on long-term growth and strategy to the EI Conference, which is only a few weeks away. Gerry Anderson will be providing our normal detailed business update at EEI. There, he will discuss our 2017 early outlook and long-term growth plans as well as details about each of the business segments. So now I'd like to start on Slide 4.
As you know in September, we raised our operating EPS guidance for 2016. At that time, we increased the guidance midpoint $0.17 to a range of $5.09 to $5.35 from a range of $4.91 to $5.19. The guidance increases were driven by a lot of weather favorability at DTE Electric, favorability across all platforms at the gas storage and pipeline business and a strong year-to-date economic performance at our trading company.
In the past, we've talked about our reinvestment strategy, holding favorability until we see the summer months play out. Well, this summer was the hottest we've had in the past 60 years, and we were able to reinvest a lot of those revenues back into the system into aging infrastructure to improve customer liability.
We've invested a nominal amount this quarter. We're stepping up our reinvestment activity for the remainder of the year. Investments will primarily be in our infrastructure, with a focus on improving immediate and lasting benefits to our customers. 
Another area where we are seeing great results this year is in safety. Now we always start every meeting with a discussion on safety and it's our #1 priority in the company. And I'm particularly pleased to announce that year-to-date, our employees continue to have the best safety record in the company's history. 
And of course, we have had a major announcement in our gas storage and pipeline segment in the third quarter with the acquisition of a gas midstream assets in the heart of the Southwest Marcellus and dry Utica basin. The transaction complements our existing midstream business and provides a platform for new value creation and significant growth opportunities. I will be discussing the growth opportunities and their impact on our business at EEI. 
Now I'd like to go over the third quarter earning results on Slide 5. For the quarter, DTE's operating earnings were $353 million, or $1.96 per share. For reference, our reported earnings were $1.88 per share and you can find a reconciliation with the third quarter reported operating earnings on Slide 17 of the appendix. For the quarter, our growth segments operating earnings were $343 million, or $1.91 per share. 
Now starting with the segments, with DTE Electric, it was higher by $71 million. This quarter was, as I indicated, when the warmest on record and drove much of this favorability. DTE Electric also supplemented a rate increase on August 1 as part of the ongoing rate case. This favorability was partially offset by increased expenses associated with the rate base growth. DTE Gas was higher by $7 million. This was primarily driven by gas, main line replacement surcharge and the storage and transport services. 
Our Power and Industrial Projects segments was higher by $3 million due primarily to higher REF earnings from additional location that came online in the fourth quarter of last year. These earnings were partially offset by lower earnings in our steel-related assets. Our Corporate and Other segment came in at $8 million favorable versus last year. This variance was mainly due to timing of taxes. Again, overall, the growth segment results for the quarter were $343 million, or $1.91 per share. 
Following with our Energy Trading segment, there were $10 million in operating earnings for the quarter and economic net income was $1 million. Please refer to Slide 15 in the appendix, which shows our standard view of the Energy Trading reconciliation of both economic and operating performance. So overall, DTE had a very strong third quarter. 
With that, moving on to Slide 6. I'd like to provide an update on our 2016 earnings guidance. As I mentioned, we recently raised 2016 guidance and are confident that we will land somewhere between the midpoint and upper end of our guidance this year. Year-to-date results are solid, and we are in good position to finish the year strong. You can see arrows next to each of the guidance numbers indicating where we think the year may play out for each segment. The green arrows indicate achieving the higher end of guidance, while the red arrows signifies the lower end. The positive signaling at DTE Electric is driven by additional weather experienced at the end of September. We had a very warm September. Our corporate and Other segment is trending towards the lower end of guidance driven by our tax true-ups. 
In the fourth quarter, we expect Energy Trading to have accounting income that covers their expenses, which puts them at the high-end of the guidance range. 
Now moving on to Slide 7. In addition to the solid earnings results, our cash flow and balance sheet are strong and continue to support a long-term growth. Based on year-to-date results, we are updating our cash flow and capital expenditure guidance. Starting at the left side of the page, we're increasing cash from operations by $200 million due to the strong cash performance year-to-date. CapEx is increasing by $1.1 billion, which is primarily due to the recent acquisition of our gas midstream assets. We're also increasing our debt financing by $900 million, which was used in part for a recent our acquisition and also for general corporate uses. 
Taking a closer look at CapEx, on the right side of the page, we show capital expenditure by business units. We still expect to invest nearly $1.6 billion at the electric company and $430 million at the gas company. We have increased the nonutility guidance by $1.1 billion. This exchange, as I mentioned, captured the purchase of the gas midstream assets. This brings our total capital expenditures to nearly $3.8 billion for the year.
Now let's move on to Slide 8, with a look at our balance sheet metrics. Our balance sheet remains strong. We expect to end the year within our targeted range for both leverage and FFO to debt. Due to the strong year-to-date earnings and cash flow, we will not be issuing equity in 2016. In early October, DTE issued $1 billion of senior notes and $675 million of mandatory convertible securities to support the midstream acquisition. As a reminder, the $675 million of mandatory convertible securities will convert to common equity in October of 2019. 
Lastly, we ended the quarter with a very healthy liquidity position of $1.6 billion. Now wrapping up on Slide 9, I will summarize the quarter, then open the line for questions. We've had another successful quarter and are in a great position to achieve our EPS guidance this year. We are looking to extend our streak to 10 consecutive years of meeting or exceeding our initial EPS guidance. We are investing heavily in our utilities by upgrading our aging infrastructure, and we are executing on growth opportunities at our nonutility businesses, most notably, the gas storage and pipeline business, where we recently added a new platform for future growth. We continue to maintain a strong balance sheet, which sets up nicely for future growth opportunities as we enter a period of significant investment and begin to transform our electric generation fleet. 
Before I open the line for questions, once again, I'd like to remind everyone that Gerry Anderson will be giving our formal business update presentation at the upcoming EEI Conference on November 8, and we hope to see many of you at the conference. But if you can't make it in person, you can visit our Investor Relations website to listen in on the webcast. 
Now I'd like to open up for questions. So Tanisha, please open the line.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question from Jonathan Arnold with Deutsche Bank.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Yes.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is on Michigan legislation. There was a story in the press talking about some kind of breakthrough and expectation that this will get taken up after the election. But it wasn't clear from that what exactly might have changed in the bill. Can y
componenttext: My question is on Michigan legislation. There was a story in the press talking about some kind of breakthrough and expectation that this will get taken up after the election. But it wasn't clear from that what exactly might have changed in the bill. Can you give any insight as to how you guys see this playing out and what there might be new to report?

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of playing out, there is definitely a strong push to get this legislation done in lame duck. There's a lot of public communication that's happening out there. Senator Nofs has made this a priority for that. It is going to be a challenge pote
componenttext: Yes, in terms of playing out, there is definitely a strong push to get this legislation done in lame duck. There's a lot of public communication that's happening out there. Senator Nofs has made this a priority for that. It is going to be a challenge potentially, given the time frame left. But I think given the focus and attention on that, there's still a chance it will happen in the lame-duck session. We have had some public support recently. The Michigan State Chamber came out publicly to support this bill so I think that's a very positive movement as well. In terms of what has changed is that, this bill in particular, is going to be a bipartisan bill. It is related to the state of Michigan, the energy reliability that's needed in the state of Michigan. So both parties need to be supportive and both parties want to get this energy legislation passed. So recently, there is some discussion on the renewable side potentially for that mandate. Currently, we're at 10%. Potentially, it will go up to 15%. That will help get some of the Democrats onboard as well. And some of the refining, as I was mentioning even when I've been on the road, that some of it is -- getting the details right around the retail open access and the capacity requirements related to that, so there is some finalization around that language. I know there is a new MISO tariff that may be out there as well that's going to help support and complement legislation as well.

headline: DTE Energy Company, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
